Basismodul 1 Traditionelle Phytotherapie  
Modulinhalt  
• Phytotherapie - aktuelle Rechtslage in der Europ äischen Union  
• Globale Relevanz von Infektionen in der Medizin und Herausforderungen in Bezug auf 
Antibiotikaresistenzen  
• Traditionelle Anwendung in der Phytotherapie  - Europ äische Phytotherapie in der 
Kloster medizin  
Lernziele: Kenntnisse der Relevanz von Antimikrobiellen Resistenzen, Surveillance -  Tools; Zugriff auf 
die Europ äischen Monografien  und Assessmentsysteme; Kenntnis der wichtigsten Kernbegriffe von 
Resistenzen  
Lernunterlagen -Lecture Notes -  Part I ; Geschichte der Europ äischen Phytotherapie (S. 3 ff. ); Lecture 
Notes, Part II Resistenzen ( S 23 ff.) Lecrure Notes, Part III Europ äische  Monographien und 
Assessmentreports (S. 82 ff.).

[I] Asynchrone Vorbereitungsphase  
 
In der Vorbereitungsphase sollen sich die Studierenden mit dem Fachthema des Moduls 
vertraut machen; Hierfür werden Videosequenzen, Textmaterialien oder 
wissenschaftliche Studien zur Verfügung gestellt (im Beispiel: galenisch)  
 
1. Video  
 Antibiotikaresistenz - VIDEO  
 Galenic – VIDEO: : wie man eine Tinktur zubereitet  
 
 Die Studierenden können zur Vorbereitung Videos mit Inhalten ansehen, die im Modul unterrichtet 
werden  
 
2. Prereading : Kapitel  Galenik  aus dem Skriptum , S. 25 (Deutsch, Englisch, Italienisch)  
 
 
 
 Die Studierenden erhalten Textreferenzen zur Vorbereitung auf die Kursinha lt

[II] Präsenzmodule –  digital / hybrid / face –  to – face  
 
In den Einheiten des Kurses wird das vorbereitete Material ausgearbeitet und mit den 
Dozenten diskutiert, in Fachvorträgen von Experten vorgetragen  und praktische 
Fähigkeiten werden in Workshops  erlernt.   Die Vorlesungsskripte werden von den 
Lehrkräften on line im Kursraum zur Verfügung gestellt.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
Die Studierenden besuchen Kurse und Workshops,  online und/oder  auch im Pr äsenzunterricht

[III] Postdidaktische Phase  
 
Die Post -Training -Phase  (Blended oder Guided E -Learning) umfasst die Bearbeitung und 
das Hochladen von Aufgaben, interaktive Foren zu Kursinhalten, Selbsttesteinheiten für 
eigene Wissenstests, die Vorbereitung auf die Kursprüfung (Skript, Kurs mitschriften , 
Video, wissenschaftliche Literatur) sowie die Abschlussprüfung mit der Vergabe von ECTS  
 
 
 
1. Quiz -Selbstprüfung  
 
 Die Studierenden können ihre Wissensbewertung nach dem Modul abschließen  
 
 
 
2. Upload - Bereich  
 
 
 
 Studierende erhalten nach dem Modul eine Aufgabe zum digitalen Hochladen  
  
3. Abschlussprüfung
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[IV] F ollow Up  
Nach Abschluss einzelner  Module oder des gesamten Kurses stehen die Online -Karteikarten für 
die weitere Verwendung am Point of Care zur Verfügung. Diese ermöglichen einen schnellen und 
einfachen Zugriff auf die wesentlichen Inhalte von Heilpflanzen für den Einsatz bei 
Atemwegsinfektionen.  
 Karteikarte (Deutsch, Englisch, Italienisch)  
 
 
 
 
 Einen Kurs erstellen – Empfehlungen  
Anteil der Vorbereitungsphase ca. 20% der Gesamtdauer des Kurses  
Teilnahme phase (Präsenz/hybrid/online) : Vorträge und Workshops ca. 5 0% der Gesamtdauer des 
Kurses  
Nachbearbeitung ca. 30% der Gesamtdauer des Kurses einschließlich der Prüfung  
Die Inhalte (ergänzende Dokumentenskripte -  digitale Toolkits) können als kompletter Kurs 
"Healthy Herbs , Thema Atemwegsinfektionen " oder als einzelne Komponenten des Moduls (z.B. 
Seminar -Galenik
) genutzt  werden.

accessto European  subsidiaries and assessment systems; Knowledge of the most important core 
concepts of resistance

[III] Course post phase  
 
The post -training phase  (blended or guided e -learning) includes the processing and 
uploading of tasks, interactive forums on course content, self- test units for your own 
knowledge tests, preparation for the course exam (script, course transcripts , video, 
scientific literature) and the final exam with the awarding of ECTS  
 
 
 
1. Quiz -self – check  (Annex to Lecture Notes – questions and solutions)  
 
 Students can complete their knowledge assessment after the module  
 
 
 
2. Upload Area  
 
 
 
 Students receive a task for digital upload after the module  
 
 
3. Final examination  
 
 
 
 
 
[IV] F ollow Up  
After completion of individual  modules or the entire course, the online index cards are available 
for further use at the point of care. These allow quick and easy access to the essential contents 
of medicinal plants for use in respiratory infections.  
 Index card (German, English, Italia n) 
 
 
 
 
 Create a Course  Recommendations   
Proportion of the preparation phase approx. 20% of the total duration of the course  
Participation phase (presence/hybrid/online) : Lectures and workshops approx. 50% of the total 
duration of the course  
Post -processing approx. 30% of the total duration of the course including the exam  
The contents (supplementary document scripts -  digital toolkits) can be 
used  as a complete course 
"Healthy Herbs , Topic Respiratory Infections " or as individual components of the module (e.g. 
Seminar  Galenics   ).

Modulo Base 1 Fitoterapia Tradizionale  
Obiettivi  
• Fitoterapia - situazione giuridica attuale nell'Unione europea  
• Rilevanza globale delle infezioni in medicina e sfide legate alla resistenza agli antibiotici  
• Applicazione tradizionale in fioterapia –  Fitoterapia europea in Monastary Medicine  
Obiettivi di apprendimento: Conoscenza della rilevanza della resistenza antimicrobica, strumenti di 
sorveglianza; l'accesso alle filiali europee e ai sistemi di valutazione; Conoscenza dei più  importanti 
concetti fondamentali di resistenza  
Materiali didattici - Dispense - Parte I; Storia della fitoterapia europea (p. 3 ss.) ;  Dispense, Parte II 
Resistenze (S 23 ss.)  Letture Notes, Part III European  Monographs and Assessment Reports (p. 82 
ss.).

La fase post -formazione  (blended o guided e -learning) comprende l'elaborazione e il 
caricamento di compiti, forum interattivi sui contenuti del corso, unità di auto -test per i 
propri test di conoscenza, preparazione all'esame del corso (script, trascrizioni  del corso, 
video, letteratura scientifica) e l'esame finale con l'assegnazione di ECTS

Fragestellung: Sind die im Mittelalter angegebenen  
vielen Indikationsangaben („Indikationslyrik“) nur  
gelegentlich richtig oder gibt es einen  
systematischen Zusammenhang mit den heute  
anerkannten Indikationen?
Design: Überprüfung aller Indikationsangaben eines  
Kräuterbuches/Autors auf Übereinstimmung mit  
heute anerkannten Indikationen (Monographien  
der Kommission E).
Mathematisches Modell zur Verteilungsfunktion  
der statistisch erwartbaren „Treffer“.
Mayer, JG, Uehleke B, Saum K: Handbuch der Klosterheilkunde. München 2002Phytotherapie: Quantitative Modelle  
zu Indikationsangaben
•Hintergrund : Mittelalterliche Indikationslyrik gemäß 4-
Säftelehre erscheint unglaubhaft und Herauspicken  
einzelner Treffer verzerrt.
•Beispiel : Hildegard von Bingen behandelt 175 heute aktuelle  
Pflanzen, davon 85 Pflanzen, die heute 310 Indikationen haben
•Indikationsmenge die Hildegard nennt I = 115
•Hildegard verteilt 437 Indikationszuweisungen auf 175  
Pflanzen
•bzw. 212 auf Indikationszuweisungen auf die 85 Pflanzen
•Hildegard gibt bei 152 Pflanzen keine richtige Indikation an, bei 18  
Pflanzen eine richtige, bei 4 Pflanzen 2 richtige, und bei 1 Pflanze  
4 richtige Indikationen an –zusammen 30„Treffer “.
•Modell: Uehleke B und Hopfenmüller W

health education among primary school pupils. St. Poelten : St. Poelten University of Applied Sciences, 2020 [Online]. Available: https://phaidra.fhstp.ac.at/open/o:4313Why ishealth literacy important ?
Health literacy is seen as a key determinant of health!
Influence on 
personal health status 
population -related health status
Low health literacy among adults is seen as one of the “triple threats to effective health communication and patient safety”
Even without profound evidence of a causal link between low health literacy and poor outcomes in terms of health , 
different findings indicate a causal relationship between them.How canwepromote health literacy ?
Connection between health education and health literacy 
Switch from “paternalistic” to “patient- centered ” models in healthcare
Need of “good” educational resources for patient for informed decision making
Written information in simple language, not too many medical/scientific terms
Use of images, video etc.
“assessment skills” for looking up information on the internet etc.
Healthcare professionals as multipliers of knowledge
e.g. by relying on traditionally used preparations instead of “first -line chemicals”
explaining why some preparations should be used with caution etc.
“help for self -help” (education on OTC drugs etc.)How canwepromote health literacy ?
hereditary transmission of knowledge
e.g. from mother to daughter
“home remedies” transferred from generation to generation

1 Health literacy and the 
public health perspective of   
phytotherapeutical  knowledge
Health Literacy 
Health Literacy can be described as t he individual’s ability to 
•search for health -related information,
•understand and
•critically assess the findings as well as
•being able to apply them to their personal situation,
which leads to thoughtful and informed health decisions.  
For example: A patient suffering from a headache, wanting to find  appropriate  medication  to stop  
his condition.1 
1 M. Seel, KARLI – Kidfriendly  Augmented Reality Learning Interface: Augmented Reality for health literacy and  
health education among primary school pupils. St. Poelten: St. Poelten University of Applied Sciences, 2020 [Online]. 
Available: https://phaidra.fhstp.ac.at/open/o:4313  
Springschool Healthy Herbs : Health literacy and the public health perspective of phytotherap. knowledge  (M. Seel)  
 
 
2 
 Blue:  use books or the internet to look for adequate over the counter (OTC) medication  and 
background  information,  such  as mechanisms  of action  or contraindication. With this information 
in mind, the patient can go to a pharmacy, discuss the options he has found and decide on an 
appropriate pain reliever.  
Green:  For a more severe or longer existing headache, he could get in touch with health 
professionals like a general practitioner. The health -literate patient can interact with the doctor at 
eye level because he can describe the symptoms and effects of his headache in a proper way. He 
can also understand  what the doctor advises him to do (e.g. to increase the daily water intake) and 
he can ask questions if needed. The doctor can issue a prescription for painkillers and explain the treatment in detail to the patient. The health -literate patient can than get the medication from the 
pharmacy and will stick to the prescribed dosage because he is aware of the consequences of non -
adherence.  
Orange:  In times of teleconsultation and healthcare hotlines, the patient can also rely on support 
via telephone. The patient phones the healthcare hotline, describes and discusses his symptoms and receives advice on his situation. With this in mind, he can then visit a pharmacy and purchase 
an adequate OTC medication.  
 
Why is this important?  
Health literacy is seen as a key determinant of health
2, therefore as part of the range of factors 
that influence the personal or population -related health status3.  
Low health literacy among adults is seen as one of the “triple threats to effective health  
communication  and patient safety”,  also enforced  by the facts  that the individual level of health 
literacy cannot be estimated by looking at a person and doctors generally overestimating the 
health literacy skills of their patients. A factor adding additional weight to low health literacy is a 
lack of literacy in general. Poor reading skills can lead to non- adherence in therapy and treatment. 
The greatest challenges  are described  regarding medication  intake  when  the patients  have 
difficulties understanding written information4. 
Even without profound evidence of a causal link between low health literacy and  poor outcomes 
in terms of health, different findings indicate a causal relationship between them.5

 How can health literacy be developed? 
• (Hea lth) education: strong connection between education and health in general; with the 
switch from a paternalistic to patient- centered perspective, the engagement of the patient 
increases,  and the patient should be empowered by being pr ovided with adequate 
resources to learn and to develop health knowledge, which influences health literacy  
 
An interesting paper from the field of physiotherapy : H. Wittink, J. Oosterhaven,  Patient 
education and health literacy,  Musculoskeletal Science and Practice,  Volume 38,  2018,  
Pages 120- 127,  ISSN 2468- 7812,  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.msksp.2018.06.004.  
(can be found on M oodle)  
 
• Health care professionals  as multipliers  of health knowledge: e.g. by relying on traditionally 
used preparations instead of “first- line chemicals” , explaining why some preparations 
should be used with caution etc. , “help for self- help” (education on OTC drugs etc.)  
 
• Hereditary knowledge transmission: e.g. within families from mother to daughter , “home 
remedies ” – part of the cultural capital of a s ociety

4 
 Home remedies  and phytotherapy as cultural capital  
Home remedies: “A traditional therapy  often  utilizing  natural  products,  nutritional  supplements,  
or physical  measures.  Its effectiveness  may  be supported  by familial,  local,  or culturally accepted  
stories  or rituals. ”6 
Knowledge about home remedies needs transmission from one generation onto the next to 
“survive” -> traditional knowledge (in families, societies etc.) is part of the cultural heritage and 
therefore of the cultural capital  
For example  
• wet feet wraps with vinegar (“Essigpatscherl”) to cure fever  
• mixtures from honey, citrus juice and hot water to treat a sore throat 
• different tea preparations  
• traditionally used phytotherapeutic preparations!  
 
Why is this important?  
Sociologists and public health researchers observe certain trends:  
• “informed patients” need sources to become “informed” - greater emphasi s should be put 
on health education and improvement of health literacy in general  
• People tend to visit the hospital or a doctor before thinking of how they could help 
themselves. Many conditions could be treated at home without the need of advanced 
medical or pharmaceutical knowledge , e.g. y oung parents prefer going to the A&E 
departmen ts instead of trying to treat their kid’s conditions at home first  
• Patients demand  antibiotic treatment without knowing the negative side effects on their 
body and the rise of antimicrobial resistances. Doctors are used to prescribing antimicrobial drugs – even in cases without indication! - because patients “want it”.  
• With a trend to chemical/synthetic medication  and ready -to-use products, we tend to 
forget about traditional home remedies and preparation s  
 
We therefore need to keep these traditions alive and transmit the knowledge to the next 
generations (by educating young mothers, teaching healthcare professionals etc.).  
This does not only promote the continued existence of home remedies and therefore a  
conservation and maintenance of cultural capital – this is also an important step towards reducing 
antimicrobial resistances and reducing the amount of antibiotics used in medicine!

•Klinische Forschung zu „Healthy Herbs“ ist eine  
Herausforderung und erfolgt unter schwierigen  
Rahmenbedigungen
•Eine evidence -based herbal medicine nach strengen  
Standards ist nur in kleinen Teilbereichen erreichbar
•Aber: eine strenge evidence -based medicine ist in weiten  
Bereichen der Medizin eine Illusion
•Meine Sicht: Eine kritisch reflektierter (und nicht von  
Werbung und ökonomischen Interesse geleiteter) Einsatz  
von „Healthy Herbs“ erscheint aber zur Vermeidung  
nebenwirkungsreicherer Therapien und als Teil einer  
patientenzentrierten Medizin sinnvoll undwünschenswertZusammenfassung

Relationtionships between terpenoid defenses and the attack of Heterobasidion
spp. in Picea abies Picea sitchensis , and Abies alba
Heterobasidion spp.  are 
recognized as some of the most 
destructive fungal pathogens of 
conifers worldwide. 
Heterobasidion species are 
responsible for the root and 
butt rot of several conifer 
species. Airborne spores of 
these pathogens land either on 
freshly cut stumps or fresh 
wounds (primary infection). 
Heterobasidion fungi infect 
uninjured trees by growth of 
the mycelium through root 
contacts or grafts (secondary 
infection ). Ecological roles of essential oil terpenes 
Monoterpene responses to interacting effects of drought stress and infection by the 
fungus Heterobasidion parviporum in two clones of Norway spruce ( Picea abies )
The specific objective of this study was to 
characterize the effects of drought stress treatment 
and H. parviporum infection on defensive 
monoterpenes in Norway spruce clones, exploring 
the mechanisms of chemical resistance to the attack 
of this pathogenic fungus in plants under drought 
stress conditions.

Bark beetle –Fungus –Conifer interaction
5-6 mmSpruce bark beetle
(Ips typographus)Ecological roles of essential oil terpenes 
Terpene Defenses
phytophagous
insect
carnivorous
insect
Volatile terpene 
signals
Constitutive and induced terpenes play the primary role of defence substances. However, through the course of evolution 
herbivores have been selected for their capability to circumvent plant chemical defences . Phytophagous beetles can be 
attracted by terpenes emitted by trees and, in addition, some monoterpene derivates have been reported as playing an 
important role in pheromonal communication. Insect predators of bark beetles are also attracted by volatile terpenes; 
thus, monoterpenes play a role in indirect plant defence at third -trophic -level interactions. Induced emission of volatile 
terpene signals warn neighbouring plants of beetle attack.Conclusion : essential oilapplications

isas old as mankind and closely linked toits
development and evolution .Indifferent eras, different
views ofhealth and disease were given, which found
expression inthecreation ofcombinations ofmedicinal
plants .The aim ofthe conception ofthese mixtures,
which wecall recipes, formulations and prescriptions,
was always the restoration ofinner balance .This basic
concept isstill used today inmodern phytomedicine,
where supporting and balancing combinations inthe
sense ofhomeostasis also play arole and find their way
into modern science and phytopharmacy .Danube University Krems, April 2022www.donau -uni.ac.at

Biofilms are characterized by the fact that 
cells are surrounded by a microbially 
induced matrix mostly of polysaccharides 
through which an aqueous solution flows. 
They may be composed of individuals of a 
single species or of mixed populations of 
different species of organisms.In biofilms , microorganisms find nutrients
and favorable conditions forreproduction .
They provide protection against natural
and artificial chemical and physical
environmental influences , e.g. pH 
environment , ionizing such asUV radiation , 
disinfectant solutions , antibiotics .Biofilms of

Phytotherapy in clinical mangement
Phyt otherapy
•Disease treatment with plants, plant formulations and their  
preparations. Mainly self-medication (with medical advice)
•Main indications
–Common cold and infections (respiratory, urinary)
–Gastro -intestinal inflammation and functional disorders
–Gynecological /urinary inflammatory/ functional disorders
–Psychiatric indications (mild to moderate severity)
–Osteoarthritis, musculo -scelettal pain
–Wound healing
Only rarely applied in: cardiovascular diesease,  
oncological disease management
Challenges of phytotherapy in clinical practice
•Abundance of available plants, preparations and  
products
•Different ethnopharmaceutical pharmacopoes:  
European rationale phytotherapy; Monastery Medicine  
Ayurveda, Chinese Medicine, Tibetan Medicine, Kampo  
a.o.
•Few knowledge of physicians about specific effects,  
safety and interactions
•In outpatient setting mostly no reimbursement by  
insurances (Germany: OTC exception list: mistletoe, St.  
Johns wort, Psyllium husks, Gingko biloba –and herbs  
inchildren
Phytotherapy in German S -3Guidelines
•Ca.30% (n=40) of AWMF guidelines contain recommendations of phytotherapy,  
of which about 30% are positive

•Urinary tract infections :u.a.horseradish, cress, bearberry leaves
•Respiratory infections :Thyme, Ivy,Primrose (primula), Plantain (Plantao,
Spitzwegerich), Cetraraia islandica (island moss), Marshmallow (Althaea,
Eibisch), Essential oils,Salvia, Echinacea, Myrte (Myrtus)
•Sore throat : lime -tree blossoms (Lindenblüten), Plantain, Arnica, Cetraria,  
Thyme, Pelargonium,
•Sinusitis : essential oils
•Colitis : psyllium seed husk, myrrh tree
•Irritable bowel syndrome: Peppermint oil, bitter preparations („Iberogast“ a.o.)
•Obstipation : psyllium husks, Aloe Vera, Senna
•Depression : St. Johns wort
•Sleep disorders : Valerian root, hops, lemon balm (Melisse),
•Cancer : mistletoe; green tea

Bernhard Uehleke•The effects of inhalation of L-menthol, D -isomenthol and  
D-neomenthol, upon nasal resistance and sensation to  
airflow were investigated in 40 subjects. L-menthol caused  
a highly significant enhancement of nasal sensation of  
airflow but despite their great similarity in structure and a  
similar peppermint smell the isomers D -isomenthol and D -
neomenthol had no effect on nasal sensation of airflow.  
These findings show that L-menthol has a specific  
pharmacological action on nasal sensory nerve endings  
which is not related to its peppermint smell. It seems that  
menthol acts upon trigeminal sensory nerve endings within  
the nose (Eccles et al., 1988).Persönliche Empfehlungen:

EMA herbal monographs
EU monographs provide all information necessary for the use of a 
medicinal product :
what the herbal product is used for;
who the herbal product is intended for;
safety information such as information regarding undesirable effects and 
interactions with other medicines.
Monographs form the basis for thesummary of product characteristics 
(SmPC) and the package leaflet. 
Two types of indications /products
Well-established use (marketing authorisation) :sufficient safety and efficacy data
Traditional use (simplified registration) : sufficient safety data and plausible 
efficacy , no proof of efficacy

parasites.

Hippocrates of Kos (460 -370 B.C.) 
The father of Western medicine was familiar with numerous drugs, 
and wrote "Corpus Hipocraticum ". 
He used ginger (warm herb) for cold. 
He described many plants: thyme, fennel, caraway, cinnamon, 
clove, anise, frankincense, myrrh, garlic, opium, mandrake, 
belladonna

… and  Galen
Galen ofPergamum was born 129 AD, now
Bergama, Turkey .Physician, philosopher, and
writer, Galen revolutionized medical theory inthe
Byzantine world, Islamic middle east, andEurope .
Galen’s medical teachings and theories would
dominate and influence Western medical science
forthenext 1,700years .
Passionate about treatments, hestudied andtravelled
extensively and long distances, inparticular inAsia
investigating and collecting plants foruse as
medicines .Hebecame legendary inhisday, aprolific
writer, andthephysician toseveral Roman Emperors .

Historical overview
Ancient galenic formulations Claudius Galen  (129-201 AD)
The father of galenic pharmacy
Today areavailable 83books, ofwhich themost
famous is Claudii Galeni de simplicium
medicamentorum facultatibus libri XIwhich
included 473medicinal plants
Galenic isthe process that turns anactive
ingredient intoaready -to-usemedicine thatcan
bedosed asrequired .A“galenic formulation”
deals with the principles ofpreparing and
compounding medicines inorder tooptimize
their absorption” .
Today ,galenic formulation isapart of
pharmaceutics, the discipline (orscience) of
dosage form design, and itisrecognised to
profoundly affect pharmacokinetics,
pharmacodynamics andsafety profile ofadrug.Galenic formulations were prepared almost
exclusively from plants by squeezing,
digesting, and other simple methods and
were widely used fortherapeutic purposes
until theendofthe15thcentury .Claudius Galen  (129-201 AD)
The father of galenic pharmacy
Hefirstly described theprocesses ofcreating extracts containing theactive
principles ofmedicinal plants within thefollowing phases :
1-Comminution(reducing themedicinal substance tosmall size
2-Penetration bythemenstruum inthemedicinal substance
3-Dissolition oftheactive principles bythemenstruum
4-Diffusion ofthedissolved active principles through thecell wall tothe
surrounding “mestrum ”
5-Separation ofthedissolved active principles from the“marc” bystraining,
filtration orexpressionV: Pharmacy
On the Powers (and Mixtures) of Simple remedies (Drugs) De Simp . 
Medicament. Facultatibus (SMT )
On Remedies Easy to Prepare: Περι ευποριστων (Peri euporiston); De Remediis 
Parabilibus
Of medicinal substitutes (On Substitute Drugs) De Substitutis Medicinis (Suc.)

Pharmaceutical preparations are defined asmedicinal products generally
consisting ofactive substances that may becombined with excipients, formulated
into adosage form suitable for the intended use, where necessary after
reconstitution, presented inasuitable and appropriately labelled container .
Pharmaceutical preparations may belicensed bythe competent authority, or
unlicensed and made tothe specific needs ofpatients according tolegislation .
Unlicensed medicines are extemporaneous preparations, i.e.pharmaceutical
preparations individually prepared foraspecific patient orpatient group, supplied
after preparation, and stock preparations, i.e.pharmaceutical preparations
prepared inadvance and stored until arequest forasupply isreceived .

Claudius Galen  (129-201 AD)
The father of galenic pharmacy
Hefirstly described theprocesses ofcreating extracts containing theactive
principles ofmedicinal plants within thefollowing phases :
1-Comminution (reducing themedicinal substance tosmall size)
2-Penetration bythemenstruum inthemedicinal substance
3-Dissolition oftheactive principles bythemenstruum
4-Diffusion ofthedissolved active principles through thecell wall tothe
surrounding “menstruum”
5-Separation ofthedissolved active principles from the“marc” bystraining,
filtration orexpression
“Menstruum” : solvent used for the 
extraction (water, wine, vinegar, oils and 
fats)
“Marc” : the inert fibrous and other insoluble 
materials remaining from the extractionMethods to obtain extracts
MACERATION
Comminuted herbal drug isplaced inacontainer with thesolvent, until
thecellular structure issoftened and penetrated bythesolvent and
soluble matter isdissolved (3-7days ).Themarc ispressed .
DIGESTION
This process isamodified form ofmaceration where thedrug is
extracted byheating .This willincrease thepenetration power ofthe
menstruum, sothat there iscomplete extraction ofthedrug.Insome
cases itisaprocess before themaceration .
INFUSION
Comminuted herbal drug isplaced inacontainer .Boiling water is
added and poured over theherb.After theherb hasbeen allowed to
steep intheliquid foranappropriate period oftime, itisremoved
(possibly bystraining) leaving aninfusion .
DECOCTION
Comminuted herbal drug isboiled withwater for10to15minutes .
After boiling, theliquid iscooled andfiltered .

Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain.In 1869, Robert Chesebrough extracted petrolatum from crude petroleum and began selling it under the 
trade name Vaseline Petroleum Jelly. Once established, Chesebrough produced a range of products 
made with petrolatum including Vaseline Cold Cream, developed in 1876. Petrolatum had a much longer 
shelf life than almond oil and was a good deal cheaper. As well as reducing the cost of making cold 
cream it extended its shelf life.

Demulcents
Aromatic 
ExpectorantsDemulcents help tothin andliquefy mucus, which inturn canhelp support
expectoration (the removal ofexcess mucus) .Thisisparticularly supportive ina
drycough orwhen there isnocough present butafeeling ofthedesire tocough .
Inthese cases, mucus maybepresent though itistoothick, hardened, andinert to
elicit acough, ortoothick andsticky toexpel effectively bycoughing .
Demulcents arecharacterized byaslightly slippery texture andoften provide a
thickening quality when infused inhotorcoldwater .
Examples :marshmallow (Althaea officinalis )root, plantain (Plantago spp.)leaf,
flower, andseed husk, licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra )root (though contraindicated
with highblood pressure), mullein (Verbascum thapsus )leaforroot, violet (Viola
spp.)leafandflower, linden (Tilia spp.)bract andflower, andoat(Avena sativa )
seed/grain etc….DemulcentsTheterm “aromatic” isreferred toherbs which boast spicy, minty, citrusy, orcamphorous scents .This
isduetosmall molecules thatcanbeeasily sensed (smelled) andthatcreate abitofmovement in
theGItract andrespiratory tract when tasted orinhaled .
Herbs witharomatic properties tend tobestimulating andcanbecharacterized aswarming orcooling .
The warming aromatics ,such asthyme (Thymus vulgaris ),oregano (Origanum vulgare ),and bee balm
(Monarda fistuloso ,M.didyma ),canhelp support damp orcold conditions andencourage expectoration .
Cooling aromatics ,such asspearmint (Mentha spicata )andpeppermint (Mentha xpiperita ),canhelp soothe
hotconditions while relaxing spasms .
Both warming andcooling aromatics willencourage movement, sothere aremany possibilities here.Because
many aromatics arealittle bitdrying ontheir own, pairing them with demulcents isagood idea toencourage
soothing movement instead ofdryirritation .
Most demulcents are best used as infusions, with some opinions on 
that to follow! Some observe that you can experience the most 
slippery, demulcent properties when you infuse these herbs over a 
long period of time. First, infuse in hot or warm water, then let it cool 
to room temperature, extending the length of the infusion. Demulcents
AromaticsExpectorants
Expectoration describes theaccelerated removal ofsecretions from thebronchi andtrachea .
This canwork byasimple combination ofdemulcent andaromatic qualities .Thedemulcency
canboth thinandaddtothevolume ofmucus, thereby aiding theexitofmucus .Thinning the
mucus makes iteasier forourbody toclear iteffectively and comfortably .Adding tothe
volume encourages reflexes thatwillpropel mucus outoftherespiratory tract.
Expectorants can work bystimulating secretions ofmucus (slightly different than
demulcents, but toasimilar effect) therefore adding tothe volume, encouraging
elimination, orsupporting secretion ofathinner mucus .
Expectorants canbewhat conventional pharmacy refers toas“mucolytic,” orasubstance
thatthins orbreaks upthephysical structure ofmucus, making iteasier forthebody toexpel .
Some plant alkaloids have this effect, forexample .Ofcourse plants often possess a
combination ofallofthese actions andrelated constituents, soasyoulearn about herbs for
lungs andrespiratory support, don’t count onbeing able tocategorize each herb ashaving
justoneofthese actions!
When demulcent and aromatic actions arecombined, themild expectorant
action ofdemulcents isaccentuated, asthearomatic action can stimulate
movement, while thedemulcent action thins mucus, soothes tissues, and
provides aslippery path forstuck mucus toexit.Expectorants are a
category ofherbs that combine demulcent andaromatic actions prettily .47AGENDA

BASIC FORMULATIONS RELATED TO GALENIC PREPARATIONS FOR
RESPIRATORY TRACT
Simple galenic preparations made ofsubstances ofplant oranimal origin include :infusions (infusa )
and decoctions (decocta ).
Infusions and decoctions arealways prepared from plant substances byinfusion .There arewater
infusions incold and boiling water .Acold infusion isobtained byinfusing theplant substance in
distilled water atroom temperature for4hours ;hot infusion -bypouring aherbal preparation
with boiling distilled water and immersing thevessel inasteam bath for5m.
Generally, formulations include: 
Solids (tablets , capsules, sachets, etc.)
Liquids (suspensions, solutions, syrups , etc.).
Semi -solids (gels, creams, ointments, etc.). 
In the practical, the following preparations are used for respiratory tract:
Liquid preparations for oral use (syrups, powders and granulates for syrups, solutions,
emulsions, suspensions, powders forsolutions orsuspensions, drops, powder fordrops) .
Solid preparation fororal use(powders, granules, capsules, tablets, cachet)
Semi -solid preparations forcutaneous application (ointments, creams, pastes, cataplasms,
medicated plasters, hydrophilic and lipophilic gels)LIQUID PREPARATIONS FOR ORAL USE 
According toPharm .Eur.10thEdition,“Liquid preparations fororaluse” are usually solutions,
emulsions orsuspensions containing one ormore active substances inasuitable vehicle ;they
may, however, consist ofliquid active substances used assuch (oral liquids) .Some preparations
fororal use areprepared bydilution ofconcentrated liquid preparations, orfrom powders or

Tablets (Compressi )
Coated tablets aretablets covered with one ormore layers ofmixtures ofvarious substances such
asnatural orsynthetic resins, gums, gelatin ,inactive and insoluble fillers, sugars, plasticisers,
polyols, waxes, colouring matter authorised bythecompetent authority and sometimes flavouring
substances and active substances .The substances used ascoatings areusually applied asasolution
orsuspension inconditions inwhich evaporation ofthevehicle occurs .When thecoating isavery
thin polymeric coating, thetablets areknown asfilm-coated tablets .Coated tablets have asmooth
surface, which isoften coloured and may bepolished ;abroken section, when examined under a
lens, shows acore surrounded byone ormore continuous layers with adifferent texture .Where
justified, uniformity ofmass oruniformity ofcontent ofcoated tablets other than film-coated
tablets may beensured bycontrol ofthecores .Film -coated tablets comply with thedisintegration
test.OROMUCOSAL PREPARATIONS ( Praeparationes buccales )
Oromucosal preparations aresolid, semi -solid orliquid preparations, containing one ormore active
substances intended foradministration tothe oral cavity and/or the throat toobtain alocal or
systemic effect .Preparations intended foralocal effect may bedesigned forapplication toaspecific
site within the oral cavity such asthe gums (gingival preparations) orthe throat (oropharyngeal
preparations) .Preparations intended forasystemic effect aredesigned tobeabsorbed primarily at
one ormore sites ontheoral mucosa (e.g.sublingual preparations) .Mucoadhesive preparations are
intended toberetained inthe oral cavity byadhesion tothe mucosal epithelium and may modify
systemic drug absorption atthesite ofapplication .Formany oromucosal preparations, itislikely that
some proportion ofthe active substance(s) will beswallowed and may beabsorbed via the
gastrointestinal tract .Advantages : 
1.Prolongs the residence time of the dosage form at the site of absorption 
2.Enhanced absorption increases the therapeutic efficacy of the drug . 
3.Increases drug bioavailability due to avoidance of first pass metabolism
4.Protects drug from degradation in the acidic environment of GIT . 
5.Improves patient compliance & ease of drug administration. 
6.Faster onset of action due to mucosal surface. MUCOADHESION

Introduction
Why aresingle -case studies needed? Themost important
didactic tool forteaching inmedicine isprobably the
description ofindividual cases .Listening toapatient’s nar-
rative ofhis/her disease, including their personal pattern of
signs andsymptoms andwhat happened once they received
treatment isremarkable .Proponents ofCAMtreatments typ-
ically refer toreports ofindividual cases tohighlight the
beneﬁts oftheir method .Butwhyisitthat, ingeneral, case
reports playaminor roleinproviding evidence toscientiﬁ -
cally prove thatatreatment iseffective?
Most case reports inCAM today areretrospective
accounts ofanimpressive case asperceived anddocu-
mented byatherapist .They serve more asanarrative to
demonstrate aproblem orthesolution toaproblem in
clinical practice andcanbeconsidered veryimportant for
teaching sessions, asadidactic tool, tohelp students
remember keyinformation .They should beexemplary and
encapsulate alltherelevant clinical issues .Awelltoldstory
ofacase willstick inone’s memory andthecrucial points
canbecalled upon ifasimilar patient appears fortreat-
ment infuture clinical practice .Sometimes observations in
single cases caneven generate newhypotheses oridentify
newtreatment options .
However, most case reports cannot beconsidered sys-
tematic research .Instead of‘‘demonstrating’’ something,
empirical research tries toanswer open questions .The
methods used must betransparent andstand acritical
evaluation .Forexample, imagine areport byatherapist
who isconvinced tohave afabulous cure forapatient
with advanced cancer .Even ifoneisonlyslightly sceptical,
numerous questions willimmediately arise:Didthepatient
truly suffer from thisspeciﬁc type ofadvanced cancer? Was
thepatient truly cured? Ifso,didhe/she receive other treat-
ments which might have contributed tothecure? Could it
have been aspontaneous remission? Only very rarely isthe
information provided intraditional single casereports sufﬁ-
cient toanswer such questions .Tobeconsidered research,
critical questions must beaddressed inacase report ora
single -case study .Inourview, thetwomost fundamen -tal
questions are:(1)Ismyobservation reliable? (2)Which
factors other than mytreatment mayexplain theobserved
outcome?
Surprisingly, thenumber ofsystematic single -case stud-
iespublished intheﬁeld ofCAM isvery small .This isa
pity,inouropinion, because such research could contributeconsiderably tothecritical evaluation ofCAMtherapies and
CAMresearch maybeneﬁt from improved understanding of
beneﬁts, limitations andutility ofsingle -cases .
Furthermore, although theworkload associated with
high-quality single -case studies must notbeunderesti -
mated, they areprobably themost feasible research tool
forthebusy practitioner .Inthisreview wewant togivean
introduction tosingle -caseresearch, topresent andexplain
single -case designs asatoolforresearch anddiscuss their
relevance andapplicability fortheclinical practice .
Thisarticle exclusively addresses single -caseresearch on
treatment effects .Theaimofallsuchresearch istoprovide
evidence forcausalities during thetherapeutic process .We
donotcover etiological, prognostic, diagnostic orproce -
dural research .Throughout thisarticle wewillusetheterm
‘‘case report’’ ifwerefer toretrospective analyses ofsin-
glepatients andtheterm ‘‘single -case study’’ ifthere isat
least some prospective element tothestudy .
Quantitative and qualitative approaches to  
single -case research
While single -case research isapplied indiverse ﬁelds, such
asmedicine, education, rehabilitation, sport andathletic
performance, ithasparticularly strong roots inpsychology .
Several textbooks summarizing methodological approaches
areavailable (e.g.Refs.1—3).These textbooks focus mainly
onexperimental single -casestudies (seebelow) withgraph -
icalandstatistical analyses .Insuch studies theinﬂuence
ofan‘‘independent variable’’ (e.g.thetreatment vs.a
control condition) onapredeﬁned outcome (e.g.blood pres-
sure) isinvestigated .Theoutcome ismeasured repeatedly
(e.g.daily over 12weeks) .Theﬁndings arethen displayed
using graphs .Speciﬁc statistical analyses areapplied totest
whether changes inoutcomes exceed those expected by
chance .4This approach tosingle -case research isstrongly
quantitatively orientated and theprinciples indrawing
inferences regarding causality donotdiffer greatly from
research performed withgroups ofindividuals .
Asecond important ﬁeldofresearch arequalitative case
studies .Thistype ofresearch isoften carried outbymed-
icalanthropologists orsocial scientists .Especially when a
researcher isinvestigating aﬁeld ofresearch where little
isknown, aqualitative case study orcase series might bea
good approach toenter theﬁeld, tocollect dataanddevelop
scientiﬁc hypotheses andtheories .Aqualitative methodAuthor's personal copy
390 M. Teut, K.Linde
mayalsobeused toidentify questions anddevelop instru -
ments forquantitative research .5Applied tothesearch for
therapeutic effects qualitative research oramixed strategy
ofqualitative andquantitative research methods (‘‘mixed
methods approach’’) isespecially valuable toexplore the
subjective andcomplex experiences andthetheoretical
concepts ofpatients andtherapists .6
Observational single -case studies and case  
reports
Observational single -case studies arescientiﬁcally lesscon-
clusive than experimental single case studies .However, as
they donotinterfere oronlyslightly interfere with routine
clinical practice, they areeasier toperform .Furthermore,
while inmany countries oneshould always obtain writ-ten
informed consent from thepatient, onedoes notneed
approval from anethical review board .
Ifyouhave verygood documentation, itwillbepossible,
atleast insome situations, toretrospectively doarigorous
caseanalysis .
From amethodological point ofview, itismuch bet-
tertoanalyze acase prospectively .Before actually starting
thetreatment, youneed todecide with thepatient what
youwillanalyze during thecourse ofthedisease anddo
thisaccurately andsystematically .Itishighly recommended
thatyouclearly formulate objectives youaimtoreach with
thetreatment, toverify theclinical diagnosis according to
thehighest standard andtocarefully document how the
course ofthedisease was—depending onthecondition
—inthelasthours, days ormonths .Oneshould usevali-
dated instruments tomeasure symptoms, signs, quality of
lifeetc.before starting thetreatment andpredeﬁne when
these aretobemeasured .Inaddition, youshould carefully
qualitatively document allimportant observations before,
during andafter treatment asneeded .Take care toensure
that several perspectives (patient, therapist, possibly also
relatives) arereﬂected inyour documentation .Detail and
consistency increase theconclusiveness more than anything
else.Youarefreetotreat asyouwould treat outside ofthe
study, butensure youdocument carefully .Anexample ofa
prospective casestudy isprovided inBox1.Themain draw-
back ofprospective case studies isthatyouhave todecide
inadvance whether youwillstudy aparticular patient .It
might bethatthispatient turns outtobenon-compliant or
thatthecourse ofdisease inthispatient isworse thaninthe
patients youusually treat.Thelikelihood ofhaving selected
apatient which isnota‘‘best’’ caseishigh.
Semi-prospective case studies could beacompromise,
balancing theadvantages ofretrospective case studies
(focus onparticularly interesting cases) andprospective
case studies (systematic documentation) .Ifearly inthe
treatment process youbecome aware that aspeciﬁc case
might beofparticular interest, youshould carefully doc-
ument what hashappened sofarand then start the
prospective documentation .
There aresome cases intheliterature where semi-
prospective methods seem tohave been used asthe
documentation isquite systematic .However, publications
ofsuch single -casestudies rarely describe their methods in

Experimental single -case designs
Experimental single -casestudies typically share twocharac -
teristics :ﬁrst, they consist ofseveral predeﬁned treatment
and/or observation phases which areoften designated as
phases A,B,C,etc.(see Fig.1).Wepropose todifferen -
tiate progressive andrepetitive approaches (see below) .
Second, theanalysis focuses onaquantitative orgraphi -
calcomparison ofthedifferent phases often using speciﬁc
statistical methods (single case statistics) .Thesequence
ortiming ofthetreatment orobservation periods canbe
non-randomized orrandomized .

(ortreatment 2),andCafollow -upphase (ortreatment

approaches inwhich, forexample, there isasecond
intervention phase (B∗)andasecond follow -upphase (C∗),
toinvestigate whether effects arelonglasting .Progressive
approaches canbeapplied inalmost anychronic conditionAuthor's personal copy

fersfrom achronic condition andsymptoms re-appear atthe

itive approaches arepossible .If,forexample, apatient

Best case series
Abestcase series isadocumentation ofanumber ofcases
which have gone particularly well.Ifsuch abestcaseseries
indicates surprisingly positive outcomes inanumber of
individuals, itcanstimulate further systematic research .
Forexample, theOfﬁce ofCancer Complementary and
Alternative Medicine (OCCAM) oftheUSNational Cancer
Institute launched abestcase series program inoncol -ogy
(http://www .cancer .gov/cam/bestcase intro.html).
Providers ofCAMtherapies areinvited tosubmit their best
cases .Tobeconsidered conclusive, reports must meet
stringent criteria .Inthecase oftheOCCAM program these
are:(1)well-documented, deﬁnitive diagnosis ofcancer ;
(2)anadequate documentation ofdisease response ;(3)
absence ofconfounders (noconcurrent treatments with
known therapeutic potential) ;(4)anadequately docu-
mented treatment history .Anexample from such abest
case series issummarized inBox4.Obviously, best case
series canbeperformed forother conditions using adapted
criteria .Box4Anexample ofabestcaseseries
Banerji etal.17published areport onabest case
series, evaluated intheprogram oftheOfﬁce ofCancer
Complementary andAlternative Medicine (OCCAM) of
theUSNational Cancer Institute .Lung andesophageal
carcinoma patients were treated with homeopathic
remedies inanIndian centre according toaspeciﬁc
(Banerji) protocol until there wascomplete regres -
sionofthetumors .Case records including pathology
andradiology reports from 14patients were submit -
tedforreview bytheUSNCIBCSProgram .Four of
these cases hadindependent conﬁrmation ofthediag-
nosis andradiographic responses andwere accepted
assufﬁcient information fortheNCItoinitiate further
investigation .Theresults ofthereview were deemed
tobesufﬁcient towarrant anNCI-initiated prospec -
tiveresearch follow -upintheform ofanobservational
study .
Single case -studies embedded in studies of groups  
ofpatients
Itispossible tointegrate single -case studies intoobserva -
tional orexperimental studies inlarger groups ofpatients .
Forexample, Hamre etal.18performed aprospective obser -
vational study ofanthroposophic arttherapy in161patients .
Within thestudy theintensity ofcomplaints, quality oflife,
depressive symptoms, useofother treatments, satisfac -
tion with thetreatment andavariety ofother outcome
measures were documented repeatedly upto24months
after inclusion .Sixteen patients were selected foraddi-
tional single case analysis forwhich additional interviews
were performed .Using ﬁgural correspondence, theauthors
tried toassess thelikelihood ofacausality ofobserved treat-
ment effects .Qualitative interviews areanexcellent toolto
further understand subjective experiences ofpatients and
therapists andcomplement quantitative data.
Walach etal.19conducted a1-year observational study
of18patients with chronic headaches, whohadpreviously
participated inaplacebo -controlled randomized trial of
classical homeopathy .Patients ﬁlled indiaries which were
analyzed using single -casestatistical methods .
Single -case studies embedded instudies ofgroups of
patients canserve tocollect additional qualitative informa -
tiontoimprove theunderstanding ofprocesses, toprovide
more detailed andindividualized evaluation andpossibly to
strengthen theconclusiveness .

Meta-analysis of single case studies
Ifmultiple single -case studies onthesame condition using
asimilar methodology become available, these canbesum-
marized inasystematic review orameta -analysis .Tothe
best ofourknowledge, thishasnotyetbeen done inCAM
duetothelackofasufﬁcient number ofsimilar single case

Cognition -based medicine (CBM) takes quite adifferent
approach toinvestigate causal inferences andisprimar -ily
applied forobservational single -case studies and case

Discussion
Single -case study designs have notyetbeen integrated
systematically orwidely intoCAM research although they
deserve much more attention .Theneed todevelop modern
methods ofcase collection, documentation andevaluation
hasalready been recognized butonlyrarely hasitbeen sys-
tematically applied .23
Webelieve thatthisisapitybecause suchresearch could
contribute considerably toacritical evaluation ofCAMther-
apies .Furthermore, although theworkload associated with
high-quality single -casestudies must notbeunderestimated
single case studies areprobably themost feasible research
toolforthebusy practitioner .
Cantheeffectiveness ofaCAMtherapy beproven bysin-
glecases? Yesandno.Inprinciple, itispossible toshow a
causal treatment effect inasingle patient with arigorous
single -casestudy .However, showing thatatreatment isgen-
erally effective inagiven condition isnotpossible (unless
there areconsistent results from alarge number ofsimilar
casestudies) .
Single -case studies aregreat instruments toimprove
theability for(self-)critical observation .They canbeused
togenerate hypotheses, tocarefully observe and to
analyze clinical processes .They canbeused inquality
assessments andserve asteaching material .Itisunlikely
thatcasestudies willprovide evidence thatwillcon-vince
skeptics, butopen clinicians maylisten carefully .Ifalarge
number ofhigh quality single -case studies would become
available combined analysis mayprovide further insights .
Insummary, itwould beunrealistic toexpect thatsingle -
case studies could revolutionize CAM research —butthey  
maywellcontribute important pieces inanevidence puzzle.
Single case study designs have certain limitations which
restrict their useinpractice :
-Themore complex atherapeutic intervention is,themore  
difﬁcult the analysis becomes.
-Introducing a combination of therapeutic interventions at  
the same time complicates the analysis.
-Acontinuous documentation ofinterventions andoutcome  
parameters is essential but a time consuming task.
-Assessment of potential bias factors can become detec -
tive’s work.
-Prospective or semi -prospective scientiﬁc case research  
requires planning, which maydelay thestart oftreatment.
-Experimental therapies may require the approval of an  
ethical board.Author's personal copy
394 M. Teut, K.Linde
The ideal conditions for most single -case studies are:
-Stable baseline, usually corresponding with chronic dis-
eases .
-Ifthedisease isselfresolving orspontaneous remissions
occur frequently, thesingle case designs might notbe
applicable .
-Introducing onlyoneneworrepeated therapeutic element
atatime.
-Nocarry -overeffects between treatment phases .
-Continuous assessment ofoutcome parameters (high num-
ber of measuring points).
-Motivated patients with good compliance.
-Clinical setting with enough time for research.
Guidelines like CONSORT statement (http://www .
consort -statement .org/)have helped toimprove thequal-
ityofclinical trials.Theimplementation oradaptation of
guidelines ondocumentation, evaluation andreviewing of
case reports might also bevery helpful forCAM case
research .24
Animportant issue todiscuss istheethics .Theapproval
ofanethical review board isconsidered necessary ifa
non-conventional orexperimental therapy istested forsci-
entiﬁc reasons, butnotincases where routine therapies are
applied fortheindividual beneﬁt ofthepatient .25Ethical
review boards areoften notfamiliar with CAM andsingle -
case research andmight seethecase inadifferent light
than aCAM researcher orpractitioner :theCAM therapy
involved might notbeatallunderstood asroutine therapy
andnearly automatically beclassiﬁed as‘‘experimental’’ .
Incases where medical treatments areinvolved, authori -
tiesmight even classify asingle -case study asavariation
ofaphase 2drug trialwith allthelegal andorganizational
consequences .
Today many medical journals invite thesubmission of
casereports, butopportunities tostudy single caseresearch
methodology arestillrare.
Webelieve thatsingle -case study designs canbeavery
useful toolforCAM researchers :forfundamental clinical
research, asapilot study andtodevelop hypotheses for
bigger andmore expensive clinical trials.They may well
bridge thegapbetween CAMpractitioners andresearchers,
asexpertise inbothﬁelds isneeded toconduct ahighquality
single -casestudy .
Especially forgeneral practitioners, single -case studies
might turnouttobeaveryinteresting ﬁeldofresearch .
